property.name: Text
property.value:
In The Siege of Erebor, multiple staging areas are in play at the same time, with a quest stage assigned to each. Player card effects at one stage cannot affect any other stage. When resolving text on a player card, consider only players at your quest stage as part of the game.
At the beginning of the round, each player, starting with the first, chooses a quest stage to be that player's main quest until the end of the round. Multiple players may choose the same quest stage. Enemies that are engages with a player remain engaged with that player when moving between stages.

property.name: Text
property.value:
At the beginning of the game, the quest stages form a line starting at 2B, The Eastern Defences, on the right (east), and ending at 5B, Erebor, on the left (west). The term "eastmost" thus refers to the stage furthest to the right that is still in play. Each phase of the game is resolved simultaneously, starting with the eastmost quest stage (i.e. 2B fully resolves the combat phase, then 3B, the 4B, then 5B, then 2B resolves the refresh phase, etc.). Within each stage, the phases are resolved in ascending player order.
The Moves West (East) keyword represents cards moving from one stage to another. If a card Moves West (East), it is moved to the nearest staging area that is still in play to the left (right) of its current location, towards (away from) Erebor. Cards at the leftmost (rightmost) stage area are immune to Moves West (East).

property.name: Text
property.value:
During the staging step, players will not reveal cards from the encounter deck in the normal way. Instead, the first player triggers Invade X, where X is the number of players in the game plus 1.
The invade keyword represents the invading forces coming from the east. When the Invade X keyword is triggered, reveal X cards from the encounter deck, one at a time. Any player at any stage can trigger responses (such as Test of Will (CORE 50) or Thalin (CORE 6)) to cards revealed by the Invade keyword.
After resolving any "When Revealed" effects on an encounter card, it is placed in an area depending on its card type: Treacheries are placed in the discard pile, enemies are placed in the eastmost staging area, and locations are placed in the staging area indicated in the bottom-right corner of the card. If the location's staging area is not in play, discard the location without resolving its "When Revealed" effects, and instead deal 2 damage to the eastmost quest stage in play.

property.name: Keywords
property.value: Adding a Quest Stage to the Victory Display

property.name: Text
property.value: When a quest stage is added to the victory display: 1) From lowest to highest engagement cost, each enemy in that stage's staging area moves west. 2) Discard each location at that quest stage from play. Then, raise the threat of each player in the game by the number of locations discarded. 3) Remove any other cards at that stage (such as objective allies or side quests) from the game. The staging area at that stage is no longer in play. 4) Each player at that stage immediately changes their main quest to the nearest quest stage to the west. Enemies engaged with a player remain engaged with that player (in contrast to changing quest stages at the beginning of the round). 5) Trigger the Forced effect on the quest stage that left play. 6) Play resumes.

property.name: Text
property.value:
Player side quests are played to the player's current staging area, and can still be chosen as the active quest by the first player in turn order at that stage during the quest phase.
The term "quest stage" refers only to the encounter quest cards 2B, 3B, 4B, or 5B, and does not refer to side quests.
There can be an active location at each quest stage, but in order to travel to a location a player must be at that quest stage during the travel phase.
